body: Hi @jixuan1989 thanks for the PR, looks good on a first qucik look. But please give me some more time to check it, then I can give you a better feedback on this : )

I think... if we omit too many files by using `-Drat.numUnapprovedLicenses`, why we run apache-rat check? 
(We run this for avoiding some new added files lack the Apache header. But, in this way, these files will be omitted..)
Therefore, if `-Drat.numUnapprovedLicenses` is the solution, I think it equals to *skip to run `mvn apache-rat:check`*.
Pls remove `@author` label, and eliminate Sonar reports (e.g., in class ServerServiceImpl.java)

> According to ut, It seems you add some bugs to our project

I have fixed the unit test that leads to failure.

> Pls remove `@author` label, and eliminate Sonar reports (e.g., in class ServerServiceImpl.java)

I have removed author remark and eliminate most sonar report that I can accept, ignoring other unreasonable sonar reports.
Can you add some unit tests to cover this bug?

The cli/lib should also be removed:

```
> rm -rf $IOTDB_HOME/data/
> rm -rf $IOTDB_HOME/lib/
```

The iotdb-cli model also need to be build, then it will generate jars in the cli/lb. So the following command may need to be replaced by:  mvn clean package -DskipTests

```
> mvn clean package -pl iotdb -am -Dmaven.test.skip=true
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8021527/54666182-12555980-4b24-11e9-9f2d-83acb01cd2ae.png)
When you build cli project, it will clean files under libs directoru

> Hi @jixuan1989 you code looks code and my only point is very minor. But overall I do not like the structure that much from an architectural point of view. I dislike that the user has to decide whether he wants to use the "robust" reader / writer or not. It should be the other way round that the "robust" reader / writer are the default and they have the "raw" reader / writer underneath them to use them. But we can solve this in a different issue perhaps. What do you think?

Hi, some questions:
- The quick start on readme.md is not identical to the quick start on
official website.
Should we remove it on readme.md, and leave a link to the website, or just
sync them up?
- There are many commands only effective on Linux/OS X in the quick start
guide. Shall we list cammands for Windows? e.g. ls rm pwd .sh
Is it suitable to show a two-columns table for each code block? One column
for Linux/OS X and the other for Windows. Do you have other better idea for
this?

> seems ok. But could you review PR 163 first and merge this PR until PR #163 is merged :)

That's ok.

> Kun Liu's comment reminds me something:
> 
> 1. addMultiPassLock() may block if the writeLock works, but addMultiPassCount does not.
> 2. In switchWaitingToWorking(),  why you still use a lock? Don't you want to make it lock-free?

The first question I have answered before, please see that in the previous conversation. 
For the second question, indeed, I find that `lock()` of `oldMultiPassLock` is unnecessary because the whole process is locked in the next step (`writeLock()`) and `unlock()` of `oldMultiPassLock` is just after unlock of the whole processor. So I remove it.

> Old files can't be deleted until no queries need these files.

That's indeed a bug, it has been fixed already.

> > Kun Liu's comment reminds me something:
> > 
> > 1. addMultiPassLock() may block if the writeLock works, but addMultiPassCount does not.
> > 2. In switchWaitingToWorking(),  why you still use a lock? Don't you want to make it lock-free?
> 
> The first question I have answered before, please see that in the previous conversation.
> For the second question, indeed, I find that `lock()` of `oldMultiPassLock` is unnecessary because the whole process is locked in the next step (`writeLock()`) and `unlock()` of `oldMultiPassLock` is just after unlock of the whole processor. So I remove it.

if newMultiPassLock.writeLock.tryLock() success, and then someone calls addMultiPassLock(), the behavior is "block", but addMultiPassCount does not...

> > > Kun Liu's comment reminds me something:
> > > 
> > > 1. addMultiPassLock() may block if the writeLock works, but addMultiPassCount does not.
> > > 2. In switchWaitingToWorking(),  why you still use a lock? Don't you want to make it lock-free?
> > 
> > 
> > The first question I have answered before, please see that in the previous conversation.
> > For the second question, indeed, I find that `lock()` of `oldMultiPassLock` is unnecessary because the whole process is locked in the next step (`writeLock()`) and `unlock()` of `oldMultiPassLock` is just after unlock of the whole processor. So I remove it.
> 
> if newMultiPassLock.writeLock.tryLock() success, and then someone calls addMultiPassLock(), the behavior is "block", but addMultiPassCount does not...

These methods are executed on the premise of acquiring the current write lock of the filenode processor, so there will be no such situation as you said.

> The difference between `IQueryProcessExecutor.java` and `IEngineQueryRouter.java `? Seems they have similar interface..

I think `IQueryProcessExecutor.java` is to handle all operation, including query and non-query operation. `IEngineQueryRouter.java` is to handle all query type operation, which is called by subclass of `IQueryProcessExecutor.java`. The name also puzzle me and it's  also a historical legacy of naming. And we can talk about the naming offline.

After change ConcurrentLinkedQueue to ConcurrentCircularArray, the performance of branch time_statistic has improved.
**result**
When  enable_performance_stat=false, almost no impact on performance.
When  enable_performance_stat=true, about 1.2258% performance degradation.

1.2% degradation is acceptable. (So, sometimes classes in JDK are not the best.)

Can you add switch for individual measurement...

I think you have missed something. The Path.getMeasurment() is called in some situations, so you cannot avoid splitting the origin path. Wrapping with a Path does not make anything more complicated.

To keep the commit log clear and meaningful, we only save one commit log in a PR. 
So, it is recommended that you squash your these commits into one commit. Otherwise, I will squash them when I merge the PR (the drawback is it seems that the commit history is made by me, rather than you..)

The behavior of the class is:

1. if append == false, the writer will be closed after it is created. 
   a. if the tsfile is broken, the behavior of the class is fixing the broken tsfile and make it sealed.
   b. if the tsfile is completed, the class does nothing.
2. if append == true, the writer will truncate some data:
   a. if the tsfile is broken, then the broken data will be truncated; (And, this PR changes the strategy: the class will try its best to save correct data)
   b. if the tsfile is completed, then the tail of the file (FileMetadata) will be truncated.

Therefore, if append == true, you must call close() in the end of your program; If append == false, you can call close() or not.

Sorry for troubling you. To be honest, I don't think you have fixed this bug. Because the original purpose was when you click some tables of contents(TOC),  jump to the appropriate contents.  Rather than just adding an "outline" in the head of contents.

> Sorry for troubling you. To be honest, I don't think you have fixed this bug. Because the original purpose was when you click some tables of contents(TOC), jump to the appropriate contents. Rather than just adding an "outline" in the head of contents.

Hi,

We have considered the original purpose, but we thought the nav-content in the head of the documents is not as convenient as on side part (as User Guide documents), so I changed it into "outline" now. Nav content on side part will probably be added in the future. Maybe I should change my description of this PR?

The commands I used in the spark-shell:
```
import org.apache.iotdb.tsfile._
val df = spark.read.tsfile("testDirect.tsfile") 
df.show
df.write.tsfile("output")
```
